item.title: Florida shooting: NRA-linked firms hit by consumer boycott
item.description: Hertz and Enterprise Holdings are among corporate partners shunning the powerful gun lobby.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Billy Morgan wins Great Britain's record fifth medal in Pyeongchang
item.description: Billy Morgan wins bronze in the men's snowboarding big air to secure Great Britain their highest medal tally in Winter Olympics history.

item.title: Trump-Russia: Manafort 'paid European ex-politicians'
item.description: President Trump's ex-campaign chief paid ex-politicians to lobby for Ukraine, an indictment says.

item.title: Plan International charity reveals child sex abuse cases
item.description: Plan International confirms six recent cases against children involving staff and volunteers.

item.title: 'Groped by Holy Mosque guard during Hajj' in Mecca
item.description: A number of women have taken to social media to say they've been sexually assaulted during the Hajj pilgrimage.

item.title: Joanna Demafelis: Employer of Filipina maid found dead in freezer arrested
item.description: The employer of a Filipina maid who was found dead in a freezer is arrested in Lebanon.

item.title: Donald Tusk: UK Brexit plans 'pure illusion'
item.description: The European Council president says reports suggest the UK is still trying to cherry pick its Brexit deal.

item.title: UK weather: Spring 'postponed' as big freeze hits UK
item.description: Freezing air from Russia could give the UK its coldest February week for five years.

item.title: Julian Assange: Ecuador says latest talks on release failed
item.description: The country's foreign minister says Ecuador will keep looking for ways to end the Wikileaks founder's case.

item.title: Labour's general secretary Iain McNicol resigns
item.description: Iain McNicol is standing down to "pursue new challenges" after seven years in the role.

item.title: Do people agree with Kylie Jenner on the Snapchat update?
item.description: We asked young people what they thought about the Snapchat after Kylie Jenner said she was no longer a fan.

item.title: Nigerian president apologises for Boko Haram schoolgirl kidnap
item.description: President Buhari apologises for the suspected abductions, as parents say 100 remain missing.

item.title: Paper review: Meat safety fears and 'more questions' for Corbyn
item.description: The Guardian reports over half of factories had "major" food safety breaches between 2014 and 2017.

item.title: Would you take somebody else's leftover medicine?
item.description: An app in Greece is helping people donate their leftover drugs to those who can't afford to buy them.

item.title: The UK's first male basketball cheerleader
item.description: After battling stereotypes, Terrell Lawrence finds his calling as a cheerleader.

item.title: Are you suffering from galanthomania?
item.description: Do you have "dirty knee syndrome"? Prize snowdrop bulbs can sell for thousands, as experts explain.

item.title: What the British think of arming teachers
item.description: President Trump says he wants some US teachers to be trained to tackle gunmen. What do British people think?

item.title: Which haircuts have been banned from schools?
item.description: The "McDonalds" haircut was banned in a Norfolk school - but it's not the first cut to cause controversy.

item.title: Stolen Degas painting Les Choristes found on a bus
item.description: The pastel artwork was taken more than eight years ago from the Musée Cantini in Marseille.

item.title: Criticism of Justin Trudeau's Bhangra dance and outfit choice
item.description: The Canadian prime minister took to the stage in Delhi, but not everybody is a fan of his dancing or outfits.

item.title: Gogglebox star quits the show to 'pursue a career in TV'
item.description: Chris Butland-Steed was part of the Channel 4 show for 10 series alongside his ex Stephen Webb.

item.title: KFC's apology for running out of chicken is pretty cheeky
item.description: The fast-food chain switched the three letters in its name around to apologise to customers.

item.title: Quiz: And Salma's joke was... what?
item.description: 7 days quiz: It's the weekly news quiz - have you been paying attention to what's been going on in the world over the past seven days?

item.title: BBC News Channel
item.description: BBC coverage of latest developments

item.title: Why do some Chinese funerals involve strippers?
item.description: Chinese authorities are once again cracking down on the practice which have existed for years.

item.title: The 'water war' brewing over the new River Nile dam
item.description: A new dam on the river Nile could trigger the world's first war about water, writes Alastair Leithead.

item.title: Rent burden 'leads to student stress'
item.description: Students are suffering from stress and anxiety owing to the pressures of housing costs, a survey has suggested.

item.title: Mobile World Congress: Why do smartphones look so alike?
item.description: Smartphone sales are falling - could the fact they increasingly have similar designs be why?

item.title: 'Why we run a boarding house for puppies'
item.description: Meet the volunteer puppy "hoteliers" who help charities meet spiralling demand for assistance dogs.

item.title: The news that made us smile this week
item.description: This week, we had the K-pop Norwegians. And the world's greatest commute. And much more.

item.title: Africans at the Winter Olympics: Inspirational - or glory-hunters?
item.description: A record number of Africans competed this year - but most of them live in the US and Europe.

item.title: The £10-a-game poker player who won $2.6m
item.description: Caravan salesman John Hesp plays poker once a month, so it was a huge shock when he went to Las Vegas and won a small fortune.

item.title: The trouble knowing how much screen time is 'too much'
item.description: Concerns about time spent online are widespread, but knowing how much is 'healthy' is difficult.

item.title: Oxfam scandal: Nine charts that show what charities do
item.description: The Oxfam revelations have raised questions about the charity sector. But what do they do?

item.title: Why Ruth Wilson is having an identity crisis
item.description: The actress wonders whether she will escape being cast as characters called Alice or Alison.

item.title: Labour and customs union: Evolution not revolution
item.description: BBC political correspondent Iain Watson on Labour's Brexit policy 'evolution'.

item.title: The low-cost mini satellites bringing mobile to the world
item.description: Billions of people still have no access to mobile services, but nano-satellites could change this.

item.title: Nationalism in heart of Europe needles EU
item.description: Alarm over migrants fuels resurgent nationalism in Central Europe, Jenny Hill reports.

item.title: Emotions run high on university pickets
item.description: Tears and anger on the picket lines as staff begin a strike at 64 universities across England.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Ester Ledecka wins second gold medal in Pyeongchang
item.description: Ester Ledecka becomes the fifth athlete to claim gold in two sports at a Winter Games with a win in the women's snowboarding parallel giant slalom.

item.title: Six Nations: England & Scotland rivalry, Wales & Ireland in 'grudge match'
item.description: England coach Eddie Jones accuses Scotland of gamesmanship as the teams prepare for Saturday's Six Nations clash and their 136th meeting.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Slalom squirrel - snowboarder narrowly avoids furry intruder
item.description: Watch as Olympic athletes from Russia's Milena Bykova narrowly avoids a collision with a squirrel on her run in the snowboarding giant slalom at the Winter Olympics.

item.title: Six Nations: France 34-17 Italy
item.description: Mathieu Bastareaud impresses on his France return as the hosts pick up a comfortable Six Nations win at the Stade Velodrome.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Great Britain bobsleigh crews out of medal contention
item.description: Both of Great Britain's four-man bobsleigh crews are out of medal contention after the first two runs with Germany leading.

item.title: Pep Guardiola: Manchester City manager charged for wearing political ribbon
item.description: Manchester City manager Pep Guardiola is charged for wearing a political message, specifically a yellow ribbon, in breach of FA regulations.

item.title: Watch the jump that secured historic GB bronze
item.description: Great Britain's Billy Morgan seals an historic bronze medal in the men's snowboard big air, making Pyeongchang 2018 GB's most successful Winter Olympics with a tally of five medals.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Norway win record 38th medal as Switzerland take team alpine skiing gold
item.description: Norway secure a record 38th medal at a Winter Olympics with bronze in the alpine skiing team event as Switzerland take gold.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Curling heartbreak, teen sensations and goals galore
item.description: Watch the best of the action from day 14 of the Winter Olympics, including Great Britain in the curling semi-final, a figure skating shock and a thrilling ice hockey encounter.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Great Britain's women curlers lose 10-5 to Sweden in semi-finals
item.description: Great Britain's women curlers lose to Sweden in the Winter Olympic semi-finals and will play Japan for a bronze medal on Saturday.

item.title: Zagitova, 15, wins figure skating gold
item.description: Alina Zagitova wins Olympic athletes from Russia's first gold medal of the 2018 Winter Olympics in the women's single figure skating.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Kelsey Serwa wins women's ski cross gold
item.description: Kelsey Serwa claims gold in the women's ski cross as part of a Canadian one-two at the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Watch Germany's 'incredible' trick shot ice hockey goal
item.description: Frank Mauer scores with an "incredible" trick shot to give Germany a 3-0 lead against Canada in their Winter Olympics ice hockey semi-final.

item.title: Olympic champion crashes out of ski cross heats
item.description: Canada's defending women's ski cross champion Marielle Thompson crashes less than 100m into the first heat of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Germany stun defending champions Canada to face OAR in men's ice hockey final
item.description: Germany reach the men's ice hockey final at the Winter Olympics for the first time by ending Canada's reign in the semi-final.

item.title: Winter Olympics: USA end 20-year wait, stunning stone & halfpipe heaven
item.description: Watch the best of the action from day 13 of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, including a thrilling women's ice-hockey final and a stunning stone in the curling.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Day-by-day guide to Pyeongchang 2018
item.description: The Britons, the medals, the highlights - everything you need to know about every day of the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Winter Olympics: GB's Dave Ryding eyes medal at Beijing 2022 after finishing ninth
item.description: Great Britain's Dave Ryding targets a medal at the 2022 Winter Olympics after finishing ninth in the slalom in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Winter Olympics: Elise Christie celebrates Sandor Liu Shaolin's relay gold
item.description: Elise Christie finally has something to celebrate as boyfriend Sandor Liu Shaolin wins the 5,000m short track relay gold in Pyeongchang.

item.title: Ethiopian cliff church gives priest daily test of faith
item.description: In the remote mountains of northern Ethiopia, a lone priest scales a 250m cliff each day to reach his church.

item.title: The dirtiest place in your kitchen might surprise you...
item.description: Lots of us use wipes to keep our kitchen surfaces clean. But is it worth it?

item.title: 'I took my wife's name - and then the hassle began'
item.description: Two men describe the difficulties they experienced when they took their wife's last name.

item.title: 'The story of a weird world I was warned never to tell'
item.description: Pauline Dakin's childhood was full of secrets, disruption and unpleasant surprises - it wasn't until many years later that she found out why.

item.title: Roman boxing gloves unearthed by Vindolanda dig
item.description: The bands of leather are "probably the only known surviving examples" of their kind.
